qas.question: Which provinces in Canada limit the rights of pharmacists in prescribing?
Who pays Australian pharmacists for doing Home Medicines Reviews?
What are pharmacists in the United Kingdom being increasingly paid for?
What fields have increased in influence on pharmacy in the United States?
What degree is now mandatory in the U.S. in order to be a licensed pharmacist?

answers.text: the Doctor of Pharmacy (Pharm. D.) degree

qas.question: Which provinces in Canada extend the rights of pharmacists in prescribing?
Who can't pay Australian pharmacists for doing Home Medicines Reviews?
What are pharmacists in the United Kingdom being paid less for?
What fields have lost influence over pharmacy in the United States?
What degree is no longer mandatory in the U.S. in order to be a licensed pharmacist?

context: This shift has already commenced in some countries; for instance, pharmacists in Australia receive remuneration from <a1_0><a1_2><b6_0>the <a1_1>Australian Government<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> for conducting comprehensive Home Medicines Reviews. In Canada, pharmacists in certain provinces have limited prescribing rights (as in <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>Alberta and British Columbia<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>) or are remunerated by their provincial government for expanded services such as medications reviews (Medschecks in Ontario). In the United Kingdom, pharmacists who undertake additional training are obtaining prescribing rights and this is because of pharmacy education. They are also being paid for by the government for <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>medicine use reviews<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. In Scotland the pharmacist can write prescriptions for Scottish registered patients of their regular medications, for the majority of drugs, except for controlled drugs, when the patient is unable to see their doctor, as could happen if they are away from home or the doctor is unavailable. In the United States, <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>pharmaceutical care or clinical pharmacy<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> has had an evolving influence on the practice of pharmacy. Moreover, <a4_2>the <a4_0><a4_1><b9_0>Doctor of Pharmacy<a4_1/> (Pharm. D.)<b9_0/><a4_0/> degree<a4_2/> is now required before entering practice and some pharmacists now complete one or two years of residency or fellowship training following graduation. In addition, consultant pharmacists, who traditionally operated primarily in nursing homes are now expanding into direct consultation with patients, under the banner of "senior care pharmacy."
